elements.content: Presented here is a chiral three-dimensional indium(III)-organic compound [In(5-Aip)2]·(TPP)·4H2O (1; 5-Aip = 5-aminoisophthalate, TPP = tetraphenylphosphonium). The structure of 1 features an unusual tetrahedral anionic framework containing tetrahedral TPP guests. This compound shows interesting photoluminescent properties and notable catalytic activity on the diethylzinc addition to benzaldehyde. The results reveal that the employment of tetrahedral TPP cations as guests can not only direct the formation of a tetrahedral framework but also help on the improvement of physical properties.
elements.clean_text: Presented here is a chiral three-dimensional indium(III)-organic compound [In(5-Aip)2]⋅(TPP)⋅4H2O (1; 5-Aip = 5-aminoisophthalate, TPP = tetraphenylphosphonium). The structure of 1 features an unusual tetrahedral anionic framework containing tetrahedral TPP guests. This compound shows interesting photoluminescent properties and notable catalytic activity on the diethylzinc addition to benzaldehyde. The results reveal that the employment of tetrahedral TPP cations as guests can not only direct the formation of a tetrahedral framework but also help on the improvement of physical properties.

elements.content: Presented here is a chiral three-dimensional Indium(III)-organic compound with an unusual tetrahedral anionic framework containing tetrahedral TPP guests, which shows interesting photoluminescent properties and notable catalytic activity on the diethylzinc addition to benzaldehyde.
elements.clean_text: Presented here is a chiral three-dimensional Indium(III)-organic compound with an unusual tetrahedral anionic framework containing tetrahedral TPP guests, which shows interesting photoluminescent properties and notable catalytic activity on the diethylzinc addition to benzaldehyde.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have recently attracted considerable interest not only for their potential applications in gas storage, separation, sensing, and heterogeneous catalysis but also for fascinating architectures and topologies. Templated synthesis is of great importance in the design and syntheses of functional materials based on MOFs. Some tetraalkylammonium cations have been widely used to assist the formation of MOFs. However, the tetraphenylphosphonium (= TPP) cation has never been considered to fabricate this aim in past years. Actually, the TPP cation with a tetrahedral configuration is good for a template agent to regulate and control the channel environment of MOFs. Moreover, it has potential catalytic and photoluminescent properties because of the presence of rich benzene rings. TPP as an auxiliary catalyst was used in some organic reaction and had a remarkable effect.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) have recently attracted considerable interest not only for their potential applications in gas storage, separation, sensing, and heterogeneous catalysis but also for fascinating architectures and topologies. Templated synthesis is of great importance in the design and syntheses of functional materials based on MOFs. Some tetraalkylammonium cations have been widely used to assist the formation of MOFs. However, the tetraphenylphosphonium (= TPP) cation has never been considered to fabricate this aim in past years. Actually, the TPP cation with a tetrahedral configuration is good for a template agent to regulate and control the channel environment of MOFs. Moreover, it has potential catalytic and photoluminescent properties because of the presence of rich benzene rings. TPP as an auxiliary catalyst was used in some organic reaction and had a remarkable effect.

elements.content: In addtion, MOF-based catalysis has become a hot topic in recent years, but it is still in an immature phase and many detailed catalytic mechanisms are worthy of further exploration. MOF-based catalysis have some typical characteristics. One promising case is the presence of active metal centers in the structure. For example, the catalytic activity of the well-known HKUST-1 and MIL-101 in the cyanosilylation of benzaldehyde was due to the well-defined accessible Lewis acidic sites exposed to the inner surface. Therefore, how to produce accessible active metal centers may be the key. Another effective approach is to construct inorganic building blocks with possible unsaturated coordination sites, typically similar to the paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 unit combined with terminal molecules, the removal of which leads to active metal sites. Another effective mean is to incorporate catalytic active metal sites into organic ligands, such as metalloporphyrins and other metalloligands with the Schiff-base unit or the binaphthyl unit.
elements.clean_text: In addtion, MOF-based catalysis has become a hot topic in recent years, but it is still in an immature phase and many detailed catalytic mechanisms are worthy of further exploration. MOF-based catalysis have some typical characteristics. One promising case is the presence of active metal centers in the structure. For example, the catalytic activity of the well-known HKUST-1 and MIL-101 in the cyanosilylation of benzaldehyde was due to the well-defined accessible Lewis acidic sites exposed to the inner surface. Therefore, how to produce accessible active metal centers may be the key. Another effective approach is to construct inorganic building blocks with possible unsaturated coordination sites, typically similar to the paddle-wheel Cu2(COO)4 unit combined with terminal molecules, the removal of which leads to active metal sites. Another effective mean is to incorporate catalytic active metal sites into organic ligands, such as metalloporphyrins and other metalloligands with the Schiff-base unit or the binaphthyl unit.

elements.content: Of particular interest is the construction of chiral MOFs for catalysis applications. Both enantiopure and achiral organic molecules can be employed to form the chiral architectures via the spatial organization of basic structural building blocks into chiral space groups. However, the generation of chirality from the achiral precursor is still unpredictable because the crystallization process tends toward centric symmetry. Meanwhile, the template agent also plays an important role in the design and synthesis of the chiral architectures.
elements.clean_text: Of particular interest is the construction of chiral MOFs for catalysis applications. Both enantiopure and achiral organic molecules can be employed to form the chiral architectures via the spatial organization of basic structural building blocks into chiral space groups. However, the generation of chirality from the achiral precursor is still unpredictable because the crystallization process tends toward centric symmetry. Meanwhile, the template agent also plays an important role in the design and synthesis of the chiral architectures.

elements.content: In this work, we report a new chiral Indium(III)-organic compound [In(5-Aip)2]·(TPP)·4H2O (1; 5-Aip = 5-aminoisophthalate) based on the achiral 5-Aip ligand and tetrahedral TPP guests. Compound 1 features a tetrahedral framework with 4-connected dia topology and shows interesting photoluminescent properties and notable catalytic activity on the diethylzinc addition to benzaldehyde.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we report a new chiral Indium(III)-organic compound [In(5-Aip)2]⋅(TPP)⋅4H2O (1; 5-Aip = 5-aminoisophthalate) based on the achiral 5-Aip ligand and tetrahedral TPP guests. Compound 1 features a tetrahedral framework with 4-connected dia topology and shows interesting photoluminescent properties and notable catalytic activity on the diethylzinc addition to benzaldehyde.

elements.content: Crystals of 1 were synthesized by a solvothermal method and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S6 of the ), IR, and circular dichroism spectrum (CD). Compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral space group I4122, indicating the chiral nature of each single crystal. The phase purity of 1 was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Figure S5 of the ).
elements.clean_text: Crystals of 1 were synthesized by a solvothermal method and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (Figure S6 of the ), IR, and circular dichroism spectrum (CD). Compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral space group I4122, indicating the chiral nature of each single crystal. The phase purity of 1 was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Figure S5 of the ).

elements.content: In the structure of 1, each In3+ ion adopts a 4-connected pattern by coordinating to eight oxygen atoms from four 5-Aip ligands. The In–O distances range from 2.192(6) to 2.378(4) Å (Figure ). Each 5-Aip ligand acts as a μ2-linker to bridge two In3+ ions. The resulting tetrahedral In(COO)4 units are further connected by the aromatic rings of the 5-Aip ligands to form an anionic three-dimensional (3D) framework, the whole large open channels are fully occupied by guest TPP cations (Figure ). In this way, the structure can be topologically represented as a 4-connected dia net. The guest TPP cations trapped into the open anionic framework of 1, to the best of our knowledge, is truly unusual and rarely known in other MOFs. That also takes some significant properties for compound 1.
elements.clean_text: In the structure of 1, each In3+ ion adopts a 4-connected pattern by coordinating to eight oxygen atoms from four 5-Aip ligands. The In-O distances range from 2.192(6) to 2.378(4) Å (Figure ). Each 5-Aip ligand acts as a μ2-linker to bridge two In3+ ions. The resulting tetrahedral In(COO)4 units are further connected by the aromatic rings of the 5-Aip ligands to form an anionic three-dimensional (3D) framework, the whole large open channels are fully occupied by guest TPP cations (Figure ). In this way, the structure can be topologically represented as a 4-connected dia net. The guest TPP cations trapped into the open anionic framework of 1, to the best of our knowledge, is truly unusual and rarely known in other MOFs. That also takes some significant properties for compound 1.

elements.content: The coordination environment in 1.
The 3D open framework of 1 containing TPP guests in the channels.
elements.clean_text: 2  The 3D open framework of 1 containing TPP guests in the channels.

elements.content: To investigate the chiral nature of 1, solid-state CD measurements on a MOS-450 instrument were performed on the solid material in KCl plates. We randomly selected different bulk crystal samples to measure the CD spectra. As shown in Figure , all measurements produce the same effect. There are obvious cotton effects at ca. 230 nm. These results demonstrate that the bulk sample of 1 is enantoriched or homochiral.
elements.clean_text: To investigate the chiral nature of 1, solid-state CD measurements on a MOS-450 instrument were performed on the solid material in KCl plates. We randomly selected different bulk crystal samples to measure the CD spectra. As shown in Figure , all measurements produce the same effect. There are obvious cotton effects at ca. 230 nm. These results demonstrate that the bulk sample of 1 is enantoriched or homochiral.

elements.content: Solid state CD spectra of 1.

The photoluminesent emission spectra of compound 1 and TPP·Br were measured in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). Compound 1 exhibits one intense emission at 400 nm upon irradiation of ultraviolet light at λex = 371 nm. The emission maximum wavelength of TPP·Br reaches to 504 nm at λex = 319 nm. Compared to TPP·Br, the π···π interactions in 1 are strengthened, including ligand-to-ligand, ligand-to-TPP, and TPP-to-TPP. The emissions of TPP·Br may be assigned to the π···π electronic transition between the benzene ring (504 nm) and the charge transfer (384 nm) involved with the benzene ring···P [π→ 3d] which has a 3d free orbital. The emission spectra of 1 and TPP·Br imply that the properties of their excited states are mainly related to their own coordination factors, such as the coordination between P and C atoms in TPP or other intramolecular interactions. Compared to the free TPP group in TPP·Br, all TPP groups in compound 1 are regularly arranged in the pore spaces. Thus, the benzene rings of TPP are limited on rotation, and compound 1 produces different photoluminescent emission from TPP·Br.
elements.clean_text: The photoluminesent emission spectra of compound 1 and TPP⋅Br were measured in the solid state at room temperature (Figure ). Compound 1 exhibits one intense emission at 400 nm upon irradiation of ultraviolet light at λex = 371 nm. The emission maximum wavelength of TPP⋅Br reaches to 504 nm at λex = 319 nm. Compared to TPP⋅Br, the π⋅⋅⋅π interactions in 1 are strengthened, including ligand-to-ligand, ligand-to-TPP, and TPP-to-TPP. The emissions of TPP⋅Br may be assigned to the π⋅⋅⋅π electronic transition between the benzene ring (504 nm) and the charge transfer (384 nm) involved with the benzene ring⋅⋅⋅P [π→ 3d] which has a 3d free orbital. The emission spectra of 1 and TPP⋅Br imply that the properties of their excited states are mainly related to their own coordination factors, such as the coordination between P and C atoms in TPP or other intramolecular interactions. Compared to the free TPP group in TPP⋅Br, all TPP groups in compound 1 are regularly arranged in the pore spaces. Thus, the benzene rings of TPP are limited on rotation, and compound 1 produces different photoluminescent emission from TPP⋅Br.

elements.content: Excitation and emission spectra of 1 and TPP·Br in the solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 4  Excitation and emission spectra of 1 and TPP⋅Br in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: To evaluate the catalytic activity of compound 1, we used the diethylzinc addition to benzylaldehyde as a test reaction (Figure a). Active catalyst 1 (24 mg) dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 8 h was placed in a 25 mL Schlenk flask and then vacuumized for 10 min. The n-hexane (2 mL) solvent was added via syringe under nitrogen. After the mixture was stirred for 30 min, benzaldehyde (25 μL) and diethylzinc (in n-hexane, 0.75 mL) were added. The new mixture was stirred under nitrogen at 25 °C. In a certain time interval, a small amount of sample was taken out and quenched with saturated NH4Cl solution. The composition of the reaction mixture was determined by GC analysis. We can observe racemic phenylpropanol (R- and S-) with the same yield in the products, indicating that there is no enatioselectivity. After 24 h, the reaction led to a 54.6% conversion of benzaldehyde and it has basically stopped (Figure b). The PXRD pattern of 1 after catalysis is consistent with that of the as-synthesized sample, which reveals the good chemical stability of 1. Compared to other reported MOF catalysts with active metal centers, compound 1 has no active metal centers in the structure because all In(III) centers in 1 are fully coordinated by the carboxylate groups. We had already taken TPP·Br to do the contrast test. The results indicated that TPP·Br has a good homogeneous catalytic effect for this reaction (Figure S4 of the ). Thus, we speculated that the guest TPP cations in 1 might play a major role in this catalytic process. Mass spectrometry (MS) was employed to check the solution after the catalytic reaction, in order to examine the possibility of leaking of the TPP cations into the solution. The obvious peak of 339.5 corresponding to the TPP cation was found (Figure S8 of the ), demonstrating the presence of the TPP cations in the solution. This result reveals that compound 1 is a special homogeneous catalyst for this reaction.
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the catalytic activity of compound 1, we used the diethylzinc addition to benzylaldehyde as a test reaction (Figure a). Active catalyst 1 (24 mg) dried under vacuum at 100 °C for 8 h was placed in a 25 mL Schlenk flask and then vacuumized for 10 min. The n-hexane (2 mL) solvent was added via syringe under nitrogen. After the mixture was stirred for 30 min, benzaldehyde (25 μL) and diethylzinc (in n-hexane, 0.75 mL) were added. The new mixture was stirred under nitrogen at 25 °C. In a certain time interval, a small amount of sample was taken out and quenched with saturated NH4Cl solution. The composition of the reaction mixture was determined by GC analysis. We can observe racemic phenylpropanol (R- and S-) with the same yield in the products, indicating that there is no enatioselectivity. After 24 h, the reaction led to a 54.6% conversion of benzaldehyde and it has basically stopped (Figure b). The PXRD pattern of 1 after catalysis is consistent with that of the as-synthesized sample, which reveals the good chemical stability of 1. Compared to other reported MOF catalysts with active metal centers, compound 1 has no active metal centers in the structure because all In(III) centers in 1 are fully coordinated by the carboxylate groups. We had already taken TPP⋅Br to do the contrast test. The results indicated that TPP⋅Br has a good homogeneous catalytic effect for this reaction (Figure S4 of the ). Thus, we speculated that the guest TPP cations in 1 might play a major role in this catalytic process. Mass spectrometry (MS) was employed to check the solution after the catalytic reaction, in order to examine the possibility of leaking of the TPP cations into the solution. The obvious peak of 339.5 corresponding to the TPP cation was found (Figure S8 of the ), demonstrating the presence of the TPP cations in the solution. This result reveals that compound 1 is a special homogeneous catalyst for this reaction.

elements.content: The change of phenylpropanol concentration with time for compound 1.
elements.clean_text: 5  The change of phenylpropanol concentration with time for compound 1.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully constructed a novel chiral coordination polymer with dia-type structure by employing achiral 5-aminoisophthalic acid and tetraphenylphosphonium bromide. Compound 1 has notable catalytic activity with the addition reaction of diethylzinc to benzaldehyde. The TPP cation reported here presents three special roles: balancing charges and supporting frameworks, enhancing photoluminescence, and catalyzing. The results demonstrated that TPP cation may serve as a good template agent for the construction of new functional materials.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully constructed a novel chiral coordination polymer with dia-type structure by employing achiral 5-aminoisophthalic acid and tetraphenylphosphonium bromide. Compound 1 has notable catalytic activity with the addition reaction of diethylzinc to benzaldehyde. The TPP cation reported here presents three special roles: balancing charges and supporting frameworks, enhancing photoluminescence, and catalyzing. The results demonstrated that TPP cation may serve as a good template agent for the construction of new functional materials.

elements.content:
Additional figures, gas chromatograph, TGA, IR, powder X-ray diffraction patterns, and CIF file. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

Synthesis of In(5-Aip)2(TPP). A mixture of In(PO3)3 (0.2 mmol), 5-Aip (0.4 mmol), TPPB (0.2 mmol), and DMF (5 mL) were sealed in a 20 mL vial and heated at 100 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. After the reaction was cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were produced (yield: 31%, based on In). IR (solid KBr pellet v/cm–1): 3450w, 3345w, 1659s, 1560m, 1379s, 747m, 528m (Figure S7 of the ).

A mixture of In(PO3)3 (0.2 mmol), 5-Aip (0.4 mmol), TPPB (0.2 mmol), and DMF (5 mL) were sealed in a 20 mL vial and heated at 100 °C for 3 days under autogenous pressure. After the reaction was cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were produced (yield: 31%, based on In). IR (solid KBr pellet v/cm-1): 3450w, 3345w, 1659s, 1560m, 1379s, 747m, 528m (Figure S7 of the ).

elements.content: Crystal data for 1: C40H38InN2O12P, M = 884.51, tetragonal, a = b = 11.9482(3) Å, c = 30.657(2) Å, V = 4376.5(3) Å3, T = 293(2) K, space group I4122, Z = 4, 4354 reflections measured, 1514 independent reflections (R int = 0.0330). The final R 1 = 0.1162 [I > 2σ(I)]. The final wR(F 2) = 0.3521 [I > 2σ(I)]. The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.148. The crystallographic calculations were conducted using the SHELXL-97 programs.

The final R 1 = 0.1162 [I > 2σ(I)]. The final wR(F 2) = 0.3521 [I > 2σ(I)]. The goodness of fit on F 2 was 1.148. The crystallographic calculations were conducted using the SHELXL-97 programs.

metadata.title:
A Chiral Tetrahedral Framework with Tetrahedral Guests
for Catalysis and Photoluminescence
